thread.title: Army will grant permits for disputed Dakota pipeline crossing
thread.title_full: Army will grant permits for disputed Dakota pipeline crossing

author: CHRISTOPHER BRENNAN
title: Army will grant permits for disputed Dakota pipeline crossing
text:
Army will grant permission for controversial Dakota Access pipeline crossing Army will grant permits for disputed Dakota pipeline crossing NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   6:06 PM 
The U.S. Army says that it will clear the way for completion of the Dakota Access pipeline by allowing controversial construction underneath the Missouri River. 
A letter to Congress from Deputy Assistant Army Secretary Paul Cramer filed in court Tuesday said that it will allow the final leg of the project at the Lake Oahe reservoir. 
Concerns about whether the $3.8 billion oil project could leak and pollute drinking water has caused large scale “water protector” protests in support of the Standing Rock Sioux. 
The Obama administration stopped construction on the pipeline in September, and in December the Army Corps of Engineers decided to deny the easement permits while it investigated the possible environmental impact. 
Army Corps ordered to allow Dakota Access pipeline construction 
Approval is now expected to come no later than Wednesday, after President Trump earlier ordered the Army to expedite its review of the easement. 
“It’s great to see this new administration following through on their promises and letting projects go forward to the benefit of American consumers and workers,” Association of Oil Pipe Lines spokesman John Stoody said. Women hold a prayer ceremony during a protest against plans to pass the Dakota Access pipeline near the Standing Rock Indian Reservation. (STEPHANIE KEITH/REUTERS) 
The Department of the Army, currently run by acting head Robert Speer, also said that it does not intend to file a report about how the pipeline could impact the environment, which could have taken years to complete. 
The land soon to be approved for the pipeline, directly north of the Stand Rock reservation, was decided after another planned route for the pipeline to take oil from North Dakota to Illinois was rejected. 
Shailene Woodley praises Malia Obama for attending DAPL protest 
One route would have taken the pipeline near the city of Bismarck, though was rejected in part because of possible effects to the North Dakota capital’s water supply, the Bismarck Tribune reported. 
The change of venue brought charges of “environmental racism” to protests, with demonstrators saying that the concerns of Native Americans were not being taken seriously. 
Clashes between police and protesters have led to more than 600 arrests, with authorities at one point using water cannons in freezing weather. Members of the clergy from across the United States participate in a march during a protest of the Dakota Access pipeline. (STEPHANIE KEITH/REUTERS) 
Protest leader Phyllis Young also says that the Army granting permission to the crossing could bring back demonstrators to the area. 
Leading lacrosse figures opposing Trump on DAPL 
The tribe is also expected to file a legal challenge to the Army easement, and attorney Jan Hasselman said that the Trump administration reversal of the Obama maneuvers shows “continues a historic pattern of broken promises to Indian Tribes and violation of treaty rights.” 
Pipeline developer Energy Transfer Partners has previously said that the project could be finished in around three months. 
With News Wire Services
